keyTakeAways: A runner named Billy Halloran was attacked by two Asiatic black bears in the Myoko woods, Japan, during a routine run in early October 2025.
The attack resulted in a broken arm and leg injuries, requiring multiple surgeries including a hip graft and metal plate insertion.
Bear attacks in Japan have increased significantly, with over 100 injuries and at least seven deaths reported this year — the highest since 2006.
Climate change is contributing to bears venturing into urban areas as traditional food sources are disrupted by altered flowering and pollination patterns.
The Japanese government has announced tougher measures to control bear populations in response to the rising number of attacks.
Local residents use precautions such as carrying bells or playing loud music to deter bears.
Halloran plans to return to running, though he acknowledges lasting psychological trauma and physical limitations.
He attributes his survival to the support of the local running community and expresses gratitude for being one of the few who survived such an attack.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Billy Halloran, a 32-year-old runner from Auckland, New Zealand, was attacked by two Asiatic black bears while jogging in the Myoko woods in Japan during early October 2025. The attack left him with a broken arm and leg, requiring multiple surgeries including a hip graft and metal plates. The incident is part of a broader surge in bear attacks across Japan, with over 100 injuries and at least seven deaths reported this year — the highest since 2006. Experts attribute this increase to climate change disrupting bear food sources, forcing bears into urban and forested areas. The Japanese government has responded by announcing tougher measures to control bear populations. Halloran, though physically and psychologically affected, remains determined to return to running and nature, crediting the support of local runners and expressing gratitude for surviving when others have not.
title: Runner wrestles bear in the Japanese woods: ‘In one bite my arm was done’
